channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire members of independent agencies — for now
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday granted the Trump administration's emergency request to fire the heads of two independent agencies. But the decision is technically a temporary one.

item.title: Jewish Museum fatal shooting raises concerns about domestic extremism
item.description: The man charged with shooting and killing a couple outside the Jewish Museum in Washington, D.C. was once a member of a far-left political group. That is raising concerns about domestic extremism.

item.title: Suspect charged with murder in killing of 2 Israeli Embassy employees
item.description: The man suspected of killing two Israeli embassy employees in Washington, D.C. has been charged with murder. Officials say they're continuing to investigate the attack as a possible hate crime.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Suspect charged with murder in killing of 2 Israeli Embassy employees, Trump administration revokes Harvard's ability to enroll international students, Supreme Court allows Trump to fire members of independent agencies.

item.title: James Comey is back with a new book, and a new controversy
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with author and former Director of the FBI, James Comey, about his latest crime novel, "FDR Drive." Comey also speaks about a recent probe into one of his Instagram posts.

item.title: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey on the city's recovery after George Floyd's death
item.description: NPR'S Michel Martin asks Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey about his city's recovery and resilience after the trauma of George Floyd's death, the protests, and violence.

item.title: What witnesses in the trial of Sean Combs have testified this week
item.description: The witnesses who have testified over the second week of the criminal trial of Sean Combs have offered context around the narrative that Cassie Ventura shared during its opening week. Isabella Gomez Sarmiento has spent the week in the courthouse in New York and reports on what the jury has heard.

item.title: A new theory on gun violence
item.description: People blame gun violence on different things depending on their political leanings. But Jens Ludwig, an economist at the University of Chicago, has found a different reason behind it. Today, we bring you a story on solutions to gun violence.

item.title: The state of civil rights in the U.S. five years after George Floyd's death
item.description: Michel Martin asks civil rights attorney Benjamin Crump about changes in the legal landscape in the years since a former Minneapolis police officer was convicted of murder in George Floyd's death.

item.title: Revisiting a music tribute to George Floyd
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin and A Martinez revisit an orchestral work composed by Adolphus Hailstork with librettist Herbert Martin paying tribute to George Floyd, five years after his death.
